Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2014 01:00PM abs44 wrote: Habibi, I just had a core needle biopsy that diagnosed PASH too. Being in a similar situation, here are my bits of info and recommendations: 1.) It is normal that the area feels different or more pronounced after the biopsy. Mine feels completely different now, which the surgeon confirmed is because it has been stabbed with a needle repeatedly and may now have some swelling/distortion from the healing process. 2.) I did not know the results when I went to see my surgeon and therefore did not know which questions to ask and left feeling like I wasn't given much information. Here are the questions I wish I would have asked (so hopefully you can ask your surgeon when you see him/her!): - Do I need to have the mass removed? If not now, will I need to down the road? (My surgeon said they wouldn't remove it but would re-evaluate in 6 months to see if I need surgery then). - What is the chance of recurrence if I have the mass removed (in other words, is the PASH all over or just in that one area)? - What are the advantages and disadvantages of doing follow-up instead of surgery? - What should I be looking for in my self-exams and how often should I be doing them? - What is your experience with PASH and should I see a breast specialist? (My surgeon clearly didn't know much about PASH - he is just a general surgeon - so I plan to see a specialist in 3 months). I hope this helps you prepare for your appt with your surgeon. There are lots of options to consider. For me, if I still have this thing in 6 months to a year from now I will probably elect to remove it simply because surgery will cost less than the frequent follow up ultrasounds and biopsies that the dr is recommending.  Good luck!
